Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: The phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for church. It was a new client, sounding a bit anxious, asking if I could walk them through some basic machine operations. As a machine repairer, I know how important it is to support clients, especially those just starting out. My company expects me to be available and helpful, and I take pride in making sure people feel confident using our equipment. But as a Christian, Sunday mornings are sacred. Attending church isn’t just a routine—it’s a commitment to my faith and my community. I could hear the choir warming up in my mind, the familiar comfort of worship calling me. Yet, on the other end of the line, the client’s uncertainty tugged at my sense of responsibility. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing in. Should I stay on the call and guide the client, or should I head out the door to join my church family? The clock ticked, and my heart pounded as I wrestled with the expectations pulling me in opposite directions.
